The spacious and elegant house belonging to
the Company, which was completed last fall, is
now open and handsomely furnished for the re-
cep,ion of visitors and boarders, under the su-
perintendence Of the Subscriber.


This WATERING PLACE is finely situated in
the high and healthy country, five miles west OF
Wilmington, commanding ALI extensive view OF
the surrounding country, the River Delaware and
the neighboring states The grounds of the
company afford pleasant and shady promenadess
and are bounded by fine streams.


The virtues Of the Waters are those OF the pur-
est Chalybeate, according to the analysis or Pro-
fessor Keating, Of Philadelphia, They have been
particularly efficacious in bilious and other fe-
yers, and are celebrated as fine tonic


The vicinity to Wilmington, offers at all times,
access to an excellent market; and the daily in
tercourie by Steam Boat lines between that
place and Newcastle, to and from Philadelphia
and Baltimore, affords facility of communica-
ton not possessed by any other Watering Place.


Parties can be accommodated at short notice
with dinners, colations, Ice creams, &c. &c.


No exertions shall be spared by the Proprietor.
10 crafty every want of the visitor to this pleas
ant and saubrlous Retreat


Charges will be moderate.


CHARLES STANLEY.


June l, 1927 3s-3m.


Nh Carriages, gigs or horses may always
be had; and there are delightful rides over good
roads, 10 the neighboring towns, villages, canal,
Sc Horses taken at livery. q. 5.

SPRINGS.

Bcef.brinc, porlS-brine, suffered to stand too
long, decaved and rotting vegetables, Particu-
larly cabbages, and other similar substances IN
cellars, &c are often the unsuspected causes o.
disease. Every house-keepcr, particularly a, at
this time Of the year, will do well to carefully
inspect m his premises, and see that nothing moi,
some or offensive is left to pollue the air N ana
near his residence. The carcases of dead
lambs cats, &C. instead of being suffered to POI,
son the atmosphere, and introduce disease a,'i
death into the family of the srmer, should be
covered with FIVE or six times their bulk OF SOIL
and suffered to remain for few months. In
this way their decomposition will impregnate,
the soil with matter which though nauseous and
poisonous to animals, is food for vegetables. IT
will be well to mix the soil with which such car
oas.s .re covered with about one part of lime tc
fvc or six of earth, and at the time OF its renov
al also mix little more quick lime with 1t to
prevent the disagreeable eiiiuvia, which may a
rise without such precaution.
CLEANSE YOUR CELLARS, SC.

THE undersigned having been appointed by
the Roreagh Council a Committe to receive Pro-
posas for a Loan not exceeding $4,000 Dollars,
on the credit of the Borough of Wilmington,
for the purpose of supplying the Borough with
water, 1t a rate of interest not exceeding five
per centum per annum, payable semi-annually,
and rembursable at the end of 90 years from the
4th of July, ls27-Notce is therefore hereby
given, that such proposals will now be received


by the undersigned at any time after the present.


date, for taking said Loan.


JAMES BROBSON,
JAMES GARDNER,
JOSEPH GRUBB,
/ WM. LARKIN,
Committee.
| Iune 1oth 1897. 39-tf

Some people pretend that mans charac-
ter NAV be learned from the shape OF his
nose. OF the shape os his head. Honest peo-
Die may be permitted TO doubt whether this
is so. but that mans character, in some
particulars, may he learned from the ap-
pcarance ct his door yard, no reasonable
IAN can doubt. II is suggested in the new
Williamstown paper, that one reason why
so many door yards are neglected, is that It
is a spot Of doubtful jurisdiction, neither tall.
ing exactly within the scope OF the word
"farM," which is the province OF the man
Is oversee, nor being properly in the house.
where the woman reigns, but ii there is any
question of this sort it ought to be settled
without DELAY, for slovenly door yard IS
nre,ty infalliblc indication OF slovenly far
mer, a slovenly wife, and slovenly house,
Old leaves, sticks, chips, bones and Oh
weeds, broken, falling fence, in short any
thing but neat door yard, is a suspicious
circumstance. The paper aforesaid Sus-
rests that "without entering on the delicate
question of right, that this province be made
over to the ladies; and that they have full
mower to call upon any idle man or boy a.
bnu, the house, to aid and abet them In Its
due regulation" r.


We think this good proposition, tor
where there is neither an idle man OF AT il,'
boy, the door yard is as neat as wax WORK

LITERATURE, WIT, AND SENTIMENT.


The June No. of "The Casket," which is
published monthly at this Office, contains
v;.w of the COTTAGE OF ST. LEON
ARDS. in Scotland, with a particular de
scrintion of that celebrated scene SO beauti-
fnllv illustrated in Walter Scou's novel of
"The heart of Mid Dothian." Also, view
Of QUEBEC, taken from the Claudiere, at
sun. setting, with an appropriate narrative
of it's romantic and picturesque scenery CO.
pied from Sillman's tour. Nos. 20. 81, ~,
and % ef"the School OF Flora, and an orig
inal song, from the pen of our admired cor
RESPONDENT "Sclim," set TO music. The con-
tents of this number abound with Original
Tales. Fssavs and Poetry, diversified by an
ecdote and useful miscellany.


Enlarged and improved as the Casket has
recently been, it now presents to the lovers
of literature, one OF the cheapest compenai-
ums of Miscellanv to be found i'll the United
States: the engravings Ghree accompanying
each number) arc in themselves worthy OF
particular attention, and will form collec-
ton at the end of the year OF upwards OF
thirty six, slperceding in value the amount
of the subscription. We do not hesitate to
say that the appearance and character oi
this work will continue to afford the ample
and satisfactory passport to public patronage
and favor. The price ct subscription is
So so cents, in advance. The volume to con-
ssist of nearly five hundred pages large octa-
vo form.


List of the Portraits and Views already published


in the Nos for this year.
| John Adams, late President OF the United
States; John Z. Calhoun, present Vice
President of the United States; Robert Full
ton, Esq the original protector of steam to
the propelling of boats; Fair Mount Water
Works, near Phiadelphia; the Capitol at
Harrisburg, Pa; Catskil Mountain House,
at the Pine Orchard, N. Y; Trenton Falls
in the state of New-York; the Cottage otSt
Leonards, in Scotland; the Port of Butfaloe
on Lake Erie; Quebec, from the Chaudiere
river: besides twenty three cuts of Plants
embellshing the "School of Flora" which
is continued in Nos: in this work; and also
several popular airs set to Music.


Orders for the Casket, (enclosing ont
years subscription addressed to .atkinso'
81 alexander, Philadelphia, will be prompt
ly attended to.

he would have permitted it, Instead of ranur-
ing the land he manures the atmosphere; and pe-
fore his dung-hill is finished he has manured an
other parish, perhaps another country Fresh
manure should be kept as carefully from the sun
and rain, as grass which is cut for hay. When
cattle have been yarded over night it might be
we'll 10 throw their manure into heaps, and COW
er them with the soil previously prepared for
that purpose.


The author of the valuable Essays, entitled
"Letters of Agricola," says "Earth IS powerful
absorber of all the gases which arise from putre-
faction. Put layer Of common soil along the
top of fermenting dung-hil from IL to IL inch
es thick and allow it to remain there While the
process is carrying on with activity, and after
wards separate it carfully from the heap, and IT
will have been impregnated with the most fer-
tilizing virtues. The composts, which OF late
have attracted so universal attention and occupi-
ed so long space in all agricultural publications
originated in the discovery of this absorbing pow
er Of the earth, and in the application Off to the
most beneficial purposes skilful agricult,l-
lst would no more think Of allowing violent
fermentation to be going on in his dung-hill,
unmxea with earth other matter, to hx and
secure the gaseous ailments, than the distilleI
would suffer his apparatus to be set at work with.
out surlnounting his still with the worm to cool
and condense the rarifed spirits, which ascend
in evaporation. In both, the most precious mat.
ter is that which assumes the Trlio"m state; and


behold it escaping with hunconcerned indifference
is demonstration Of the most profound iSnor
ance."

A lady Of Yorkshire observes, III letter DAT
cd March Cd, that in consequence OF looslng her
first three children; one during teethmg' ana
two Of innamation in the bowels she gave her
f,,rth ch,ld a little lime water in every article OF
food, adding desert, and some times only tea
spoon full Of lime water to every article, whether
LIQUID or thick. 1t succeeded in keeping up
healthy digestion, and regular state of the bow
els: the child, instead Of being feversh, fatulent
and fretful, as her preceding children had been,
continued cool and cheerful tree from any
without apv constitutional disturbance
has continued this practice with two more OF
her children with the same effects: We have ave
Known This simple addition to the food of chill.
dren prove very cfticacious in inclpient cases OF
rickets and Of irritable bowels, attended with
loosencss, &C.; but if the chid be aisposeu 70
cost;vcness. on account of its astringent quality,
a little magnesia should be occasionally added to
ru1IDREN'S FOOD.

ORCHARD GRASS.

This curious appendage 10 the trees is first Wis.
ible in the cypress swamps at about 80 degrees,
and is seen thence to the gulf. 1t is the constant
accompaniment of the trees in deep bottoms
and swampy lands, and seems to be an indica-
ton of the degree ofhumidity in the atmosphere.
have observed that in dry and hilly pine woods,
far from streams and stagnant waters, it almost
wholly disappears; but in the pine woods it
reappears as you approach bottoms, streams and
swamps. | have remarked too, that where it so
completely envelopes the cypress, as to show
nothing but the festoons ofthe dark grey moss,
other trees are wholly free from it. 1t seems
less inclined to attach itself to the cotton wood
trees than to any other.


This moss is plant of the parasitcal species,
being propagatcd by seed, which forms capsule
that is preceded by very minute but beautiful
purple flower. Although when the trees that
have cast their leaves are covered with it, they
look Us if they were dead, yet the moss will moi
live on dead tree. II is well known that thi!
moss when managed by process like that ofpre
pairing hemp or fax, separates from its bark, ant
the black fibre that remains is not unlike horse
! hair elastic, ncowuptible, and an admirab" anc
cheap article for mattresses, Of which are formed
most Of the beds cf the southern people otthl
region.

Not only the careases of animals, but stable


and barn yard manure is rendered OF but little


value by long exposure to the air, sun and wet
weather. Indeed every moment OF such expo
sure robs it of some part of its fcrtiizing prnci-
nles. as well as contaminates the atmosphere -
"He who is within the sphere of the scent ofa
dung-hill," says the celebrated Arthur Young,
essmells that which his crop would have eaten II

ing horses to take care OF. Satisfactory recon-
mendation can be given by applying at this Of

Mrs. Clarissa Tier died in Neville. about
so miles from the city Of Cincinnati, on the
10Th April. Her death was supposed to be
caused by fright. AS she was sitting at
home in the evening, "A young man impru-
dently wrapped himself in white sheet
and came into the house. Mrs Her being
in a delicate state Of health, the fright
brought ON an illness, from which she never
recovered.

We have seen very ingenious and useful
Workb Mr.. Il. Touson, an eminent Surgeon
ana Lecturer on Anatomy, clearly explaining
me Muscles of the Human body, by means of
Plates peculiarly contlved-each muscle can be
rlsed, and the successive LAYERS exhibited, until
'e bones are exposed, thus showing their orr
ENs, Insertions, positions, and shapes at one
view. II is the intention of the Author to pub
mh the Arteries on n similar plan; in fact, the
Whole human frame, which will be great desd-
eIa'um to all engaged in anatomical pursuits
we are happy to find that Mr., Tusons labors
uave been crowned with success, the work being

full articles.headline:
BranAywine ChaAybeate


SPRINGS.
full articles.article:
The spacious and elegant house belonging to
the Company, which was completed last fall, is
now open and handsomely furnished for the re-
cep,ion of visitors and boarders, under the su-
perintendence Of the Subscriber.


This WATERING PLACE is finely situated in
the high and healthy country, five miles west OF
Wilmington, commanding ALI extensive view OF
the surrounding country, the River Delaware and
the neighboring states The grounds of the
company afford pleasant and shady promenadess
and are bounded by fine streams.


The virtues Of the Waters are those OF the pur-
est Chalybeate, according to the analysis or Pro-
fessor Keating, Of Philadelphia, They have been
particularly efficacious in bilious and other fe-
yers, and are celebrated as fine tonic


The vicinity to Wilmington, offers at all times,
access to an excellent market; and the daily in
tercourie by Steam Boat lines between that
place and Newcastle, to and from Philadelphia
and Baltimore, affords facility of communica-
ton not possessed by any other Watering Place.


Parties can be accommodated at short notice
with dinners, colations, Ice creams, &c. &c.


No exertions shall be spared by the Proprietor.
10 crafty every want of the visitor to this pleas
ant and saubrlous Retreat


Charges will be moderate.


CHARLES STANLEY.


June l, 1927 3s-3m.


Nh Carriages, gigs or horses may always
be had; and there are delightful rides over good
roads, 10 the neighboring towns, villages, canal,
Sc Horses taken at livery. q. 5.

full articles.headline: CLEANSE YOUR CELLARS, SC.
full articles.article:
Bcef.brinc, porlS-brine, suffered to stand too
long, decaved and rotting vegetables, Particu-
larly cabbages, and other similar substances IN
cellars, &c are often the unsuspected causes o.
disease. Every house-keepcr, particularly a, at
this time Of the year, will do well to carefully
inspect m his premises, and see that nothing moi,
some or offensive is left to pollue the air N ana
near his residence. The carcases of dead
lambs cats, &C. instead of being suffered to POI,
son the atmosphere, and introduce disease a,'i
death into the family of the srmer, should be
covered with FIVE or six times their bulk OF SOIL
and suffered to remain for few months. In
this way their decomposition will impregnate,
the soil with matter which though nauseous and
poisonous to animals, is food for vegetables. IT
will be well to mix the soil with which such car
oas.s .re covered with about one part of lime tc
fvc or six of earth, and at the time OF its renov
al also mix little more quick lime with 1t to
prevent the disagreeable eiiiuvia, which may a
rise without such precaution.

full articles.headline: Borough loan.
full articles.article:
THE undersigned having been appointed by
the Roreagh Council a Committe to receive Pro-
posas for a Loan not exceeding $4,000 Dollars,
on the credit of the Borough of Wilmington,
for the purpose of supplying the Borough with
water, 1t a rate of interest not exceeding five
per centum per annum, payable semi-annually,
and rembursable at the end of 90 years from the
4th of July, ls27-Notce is therefore hereby
given, that such proposals will now be received


by the undersigned at any time after the present.


date, for taking said Loan.


JAMES BROBSON,
JAMES GARDNER,
JOSEPH GRUBB,
/ WM. LARKIN,
Committee.
| Iune 1oth 1897. 39-tf

full articles.headline:
ES1ErHsesTIS MSSN S1E

DOOR YARD.
full articles.article:
Some people pretend that mans charac-
ter NAV be learned from the shape OF his
nose. OF the shape os his head. Honest peo-
Die may be permitted TO doubt whether this
is so. but that mans character, in some
particulars, may he learned from the ap-
pcarance ct his door yard, no reasonable
IAN can doubt. II is suggested in the new
Williamstown paper, that one reason why
so many door yards are neglected, is that It
is a spot Of doubtful jurisdiction, neither tall.
ing exactly within the scope OF the word
"farM," which is the province OF the man
Is oversee, nor being properly in the house.
where the woman reigns, but ii there is any
question of this sort it ought to be settled
without DELAY, for slovenly door yard IS
nre,ty infalliblc indication OF slovenly far
mer, a slovenly wife, and slovenly house,
Old leaves, sticks, chips, bones and Oh
weeds, broken, falling fence, in short any
thing but neat door yard, is a suspicious
circumstance. The paper aforesaid Sus-
rests that "without entering on the delicate
question of right, that this province be made
over to the ladies; and that they have full
mower to call upon any idle man or boy a.
bnu, the house, to aid and abet them In Its
due regulation" r.


We think this good proposition, tor
where there is neither an idle man OF AT il,'
boy, the door yard is as neat as wax WORK

full articles.headline: TE7E CMSKEy,
full articles.article:
LITERATURE, WIT, AND SENTIMENT.


The June No. of "The Casket," which is
published monthly at this Office, contains
v;.w of the COTTAGE OF ST. LEON
ARDS. in Scotland, with a particular de
scrintion of that celebrated scene SO beauti-
fnllv illustrated in Walter Scou's novel of
"The heart of Mid Dothian." Also, view
Of QUEBEC, taken from the Claudiere, at
sun. setting, with an appropriate narrative
of it's romantic and picturesque scenery CO.
pied from Sillman's tour. Nos. 20. 81, ~,
and % ef"the School OF Flora, and an orig
inal song, from the pen of our admired cor
RESPONDENT "Sclim," set TO music. The con-
tents of this number abound with Original
Tales. Fssavs and Poetry, diversified by an
ecdote and useful miscellany.


Enlarged and improved as the Casket has
recently been, it now presents to the lovers
of literature, one OF the cheapest compenai-
ums of Miscellanv to be found i'll the United
States: the engravings Ghree accompanying
each number) arc in themselves worthy OF
particular attention, and will form collec-
ton at the end of the year OF upwards OF
thirty six, slperceding in value the amount
of the subscription. We do not hesitate to
say that the appearance and character oi
this work will continue to afford the ample
and satisfactory passport to public patronage
and favor. The price ct subscription is
So so cents, in advance. The volume to con-
ssist of nearly five hundred pages large octa-
vo form.


List of the Portraits and Views already published


in the Nos for this year.
| John Adams, late President OF the United
States; John Z. Calhoun, present Vice
President of the United States; Robert Full
ton, Esq the original protector of steam to
the propelling of boats; Fair Mount Water
Works, near Phiadelphia; the Capitol at
Harrisburg, Pa; Catskil Mountain House,
at the Pine Orchard, N. Y; Trenton Falls
in the state of New-York; the Cottage otSt
Leonards, in Scotland; the Port of Butfaloe
on Lake Erie; Quebec, from the Chaudiere
river: besides twenty three cuts of Plants
embellshing the "School of Flora" which
is continued in Nos: in this work; and also
several popular airs set to Music.


Orders for the Casket, (enclosing ont
years subscription addressed to .atkinso'
81 alexander, Philadelphia, will be prompt
ly attended to.


Editors of papers who oblge US with al
exchange will confer an obligation by insert
ing the above. "A. & n.

he would have permitted it, Instead of ranur-
ing the land he manures the atmosphere; and pe-
fore his dung-hill is finished he has manured an
other parish, perhaps another country Fresh
manure should be kept as carefully from the sun
and rain, as grass which is cut for hay. When
cattle have been yarded over night it might be
we'll 10 throw their manure into heaps, and COW
er them with the soil previously prepared for
that purpose.


The author of the valuable Essays, entitled
"Letters of Agricola," says "Earth IS powerful
absorber of all the gases which arise from putre-
faction. Put layer Of common soil along the
top of fermenting dung-hil from IL to IL inch
es thick and allow it to remain there While the
process is carrying on with activity, and after
wards separate it carfully from the heap, and IT
will have been impregnated with the most fer-
tilizing virtues. The composts, which OF late
have attracted so universal attention and occupi-
ed so long space in all agricultural publications
originated in the discovery of this absorbing pow
er Of the earth, and in the application Off to the
most beneficial purposes skilful agricult,l-
lst would no more think Of allowing violent
fermentation to be going on in his dung-hill,
unmxea with earth other matter, to hx and
secure the gaseous ailments, than the distilleI
would suffer his apparatus to be set at work with.
out surlnounting his still with the worm to cool
and condense the rarifed spirits, which ascend
in evaporation. In both, the most precious mat.
ter is that which assumes the Trlio"m state; and


behold it escaping with hunconcerned indifference
is demonstration Of the most profound iSnor
ance."

full articles.headline: ru1IDREN'S FOOD.
full articles.article:
A lady Of Yorkshire observes, III letter DAT
cd March Cd, that in consequence OF looslng her
first three children; one during teethmg' ana
two Of innamation in the bowels she gave her
f,,rth ch,ld a little lime water in every article OF
food, adding desert, and some times only tea
spoon full Of lime water to every article, whether
LIQUID or thick. 1t succeeded in keeping up
healthy digestion, and regular state of the bow
els: the child, instead Of being feversh, fatulent
and fretful, as her preceding children had been,
continued cool and cheerful tree from any
without apv constitutional disturbance
has continued this practice with two more OF
her children with the same effects: We have ave
Known This simple addition to the food of chill.
dren prove very cfticacious in inclpient cases OF
rickets and Of irritable bowels, attended with
loosencss, &C.; but if the chid be aisposeu 70
cost;vcness. on account of its astringent quality,
a little magnesia should be occasionally added to

full articles.headline: ORCHARD GRASS.
full articles.article:
As an instance in addition to those which
we have already noticed. of the productive
ness of the present year, we were shown on
Saturday last, bunch of Orchard Grass,
raised upon the farm of John Hare Powell
Esq. Of Powelton. containing several stalks
that measured FIVE feet four inches high,
1t was taken from field of thirty acres oi
the same kind Of grass, much of which we
are informed is but little inferior to the spe-
cimcn above mentioned


Pdila fa

This curious appendage 10 the trees is first Wis.
ible in the cypress swamps at about 80 degrees,
and is seen thence to the gulf. 1t is the constant
accompaniment of the trees in deep bottoms
and swampy lands, and seems to be an indica-
ton of the degree ofhumidity in the atmosphere.
have observed that in dry and hilly pine woods,
far from streams and stagnant waters, it almost
wholly disappears; but in the pine woods it
reappears as you approach bottoms, streams and
swamps. | have remarked too, that where it so
completely envelopes the cypress, as to show
nothing but the festoons ofthe dark grey moss,
other trees are wholly free from it. 1t seems
less inclined to attach itself to the cotton wood
trees than to any other.


This moss is plant of the parasitcal species,
being propagatcd by seed, which forms capsule
that is preceded by very minute but beautiful
purple flower. Although when the trees that
have cast their leaves are covered with it, they
look Us if they were dead, yet the moss will moi
live on dead tree. II is well known that thi!
moss when managed by process like that ofpre
pairing hemp or fax, separates from its bark, ant
the black fibre that remains is not unlike horse
! hair elastic, ncowuptible, and an admirab" anc
cheap article for mattresses, Of which are formed
most Of the beds cf the southern people otthl
region.

ea of rank. among whom was Mr.. Jenkh,

y, Y. '' With intent TO study the law. At the

sa% "~ society. which met in Bond street ana
ns h;s nractice there, acquired that ease ana
% %scility in public speaking which he no" SO
cminently possesses.

full articles.headline: F,eeioe .9paytmeats from nariious .q,r.
full articles.article:
DIR. T. Cooper gives tile following directions
for that purpose. ''Some common spirit OF salt
may be kept in one bottle, and some manganese
in anothcr the manganese may be strewed on a
plate or large saucer, and this may be placed
over boiling water, chafng dr.h of Goals or a
small lanp the spirit Of salt may be poured on
the manganese, when the chlorine gas will be ex-
tricaca by the heat. 1t will be prudent to go
out OF The room and avoid the fumes, which
bring on very obstinate coughing. Attera short
time, the room may be ventilated, and then
washed and whitewashcd. great many 9th
CIR recipes have been given for producing the
same effect, but none, which we should Judge to
be more simple and eficctaal than that mentlcn'
cd above.

p,,,ment. falling oytrboald from the Chaholy
hgS i.aan, boat. between long Point and Montreal
.nd co n,iraculousy appearing on me neach PC
eS.Lis comrades had disembarkcd reminded me
~ aircumstance that occurred during my scr
';,nIs on hoard the Dolphin man-ot-war, bouha

man oyerboardl!i wa9 the general cry lore

Tom, who was a tolelably GOOD swimmer 's

70 be seen "IIe is gonc," said they, TO Davy \
lockcr" and efforts ceased. :,


Our shin was very deep, bound out TO the
West Indies consequently our gun room pnf'S
were low in the water. This Tom saw, ana rs
it was getting dark, he thought he would w.lt
iii they had beat to quarters, and plpeu 'nc
hammocks down, bcfole they got on board,
which he did and then popped down into the
adys hold, (whcrc the gunner keeps hls wads
and snare monkey taila) and there renamed III
the middle of the first watch, when he sailed
forth and made free with our bags, taking
.nourb to serve him for three days At the enc
ofths time, we were jlcging along AZ an easy
rate, with ely any Wind, about a knot, whct
master Tom, unobscwcd, slips out of the ror
lie came in at, and dropping astein began I,

.ays the Quartcrmaser, who was abait getting
pall Of the mainbracc Says Tom, I'll yon don,
! lack the naintopsail and heavc to, shall slnk
for no man can swim to the vest Indies wiihou
provisions"


Every body run aft in amusement, for it ha,
been blowing fresh during the time We suppos
cd he had been overheard, but there was no tim
to be iost--so the boat WAS lowered, and poo
Tom picked up, to the great qualification and aa

On our arrival, as the Captain was on shor
dining with the Governor, the talk turned upo
swimming The Governor was extoling tn
powers of a black man he had and our captai
swore no man could swim with Tom Garboarc
Of the Dolphin's iorctop; however, to make
long story short, the Captain and the Govcrnc
made a heavy bct--the time was appointed
Tom asked one week to get ready.


The carpenters were ordered to make VIII;
chests and convcniences Tom required. ri
purser was instructed at his request to supply
fortnights provisions. The day came and To
went on shore at the wharf appointed when |
hegan to stow his grub. The black fellow loo
ri at him with astonishmcnt-"what you
dcrc, massa" says he; "what am doing here
says Tom, "why am taking in my provision
% be sure, and advise you to do the same,
damn the bit ofthis do you get on the road, ="
"Why, massa," says the negro, sine no sw
more nine ten miles" ''Nine or ten miles
says Tom, rs ifin amazement at the short Il


ance, "why, man, I'm going to Tobago, viii
lbelievc is over 200 miles, and shan't be ba


Tor a fortnight"


The spectators were astoun1-a, The bla
refused TO swim The governor lost his wag
and it was not until We were homeward bou
that Tom told the secret.


BOB TRANSOM.

full articles.headline: MAKE THE MOST OF YOUR MANURE.
full articles.article:
Not only the careases of animals, but stable


and barn yard manure is rendered OF but little


value by long exposure to the air, sun and wet
weather. Indeed every moment OF such expo
sure robs it of some part of its fcrtiizing prnci-
nles. as well as contaminates the atmosphere -
"He who is within the sphere of the scent ofa
dung-hill," says the celebrated Arthur Young,
essmells that which his crop would have eaten II

full articles.headline: A Situation Wanted.
full articles.article:
A young Black Man Of good character wants e
situation. He is acquainted with the ordinary
business of farmer, and would be willing to hire
as such. He is also well acquainted with honse
work, cooking, &c. and would suit any one hav-
ing horses to take care OF. Satisfactory recon-
mendation can be given by applying at this Of
flee.


June ID, 1927.

Valparaiso papers to The Goth February, ndi-
cate some political agitation there, between the
Bolivar and Federal parties. The Government
is to be re-organi1ed, and this subject naturally
produces warmth Of discussion. One OF the pa
,ers says that Bolivar IS quite changed since the
battle OF Ayacuclo. We wish we had better
materials to work with.-Bah. amer.

The Museum fthe Literary and Philc-

riched by the receipt Of three cases Of min

lection Of beautiful spccimes--the third, a

the mountains ard mines Of TlalpiJahua.

Mrs. Clarissa Tier died in Neville. about
so miles from the city Of Cincinnati, on the
10Th April. Her death was supposed to be
caused by fright. AS she was sitting at
home in the evening, "A young man impru-
dently wrapped himself in white sheet
and came into the house. Mrs Her being
in a delicate state Of health, the fright
brought ON an illness, from which she never
recovered.

full articles.headline: THE ARKANSAS,
full articles.article:
From Fltat's Eaily If The MisoissVpi.


We continued 10 float ON through the deep !
and inundated forest, when at righ, angles to oar
course. we discovered another opening. TWAS
the Arkansas moving on with majestic current
of water; of the color Of arnotto dye. This IS,
next to the Missouri, the largest and most inter
! esting tributary Of the Mississippi, and from ITS


mouth b., It's mcandcrs to the mountains IS com


monty computed about 1000 miles. lls course


has been traced in these mountains at least hvc
hundred miles, and il is believed that the source


ofthc Arkansas has not yet been c%plor d by our


pcorlc One singularity distinguished thisrivcr
from any other the United states. Where It


winds along among The mountains, all agree that


il is bread aud deep river, and carries great


volume of water. But no sooner does IT emerge


fron the shelter ofthe woods and mountains M


to a boundlcss and arid plain, composed TO


great depth uF ouicksands, than il begins 70 dis
appear; and ii hundred miles from the very ei-
cvatcd mountain near which i enters upon tnc


plain, it is formidable during the summer. SUI
lower down il Is a stream, Accord & to the wr"
, known phrase OF the eonraJ', ta'ink N the


yand," that IS, il trickles amidst tic banks OF


sand and pebbles, so AS in naiiy places TO eXhio't
,lry channel of burning sanl ttor' bank t. bank
Here on these vast SANDY plains, which will Tor


ares be the Syrtcs Of America, The home OF eiH'
. and buiFsloes arc the Wild fields Of those rch


native cranes that all travellers in these regions
have spoken of in terms of such admiration -


They are said to be conica N shape, large. OF
/ beautiful blue, ard transparent he arVins
. sands rise round the stem, that advance. S'i


above the sand This sand performs the bes'
. Office Of pruning, covering the superiiuous
growth and foliage, inhcting no woNnss, ahd


aHorlnr most admirable method OF rpehilS
the clusters in the highest perfection by the Fc-
: aecton of the sun from the sand. in The eXre-
" dtion of Mai Long, the extreme sweetness OF
= thesc cranes is recorded, and other travellers
!, have borne the same testimony. They speak OF
y :, vast tracts covered with these rich clusters
~ shall have occasion elsewhere 70 speak ot inc
: classes Of this native grape, which are 50 mncn


extollcd in the Internal provinces o' Spaln'-
~ They arc common through the pine woods o.
~ Louisiana, and known by the name OF the pine
woods grape.
~ This grape ripens in juno. Y would propa
~ by be an admirable grape to cultivate. Iher'
!, arc also varieties Of autunnal grapes, ana won
IN derful accounts are given Of the immense qnah
- titles Of grapes that rpen on the sand plains at th
70 sources Of Red river Thc hunters assert Una
~ they are richer than any cultivated grape


At distance of mile or two from the rFci
IN there arc first thick cane brakes, then series
;, lakes xactly resembling the rycrin their point
is. and bends, and in the color OF their wa,erS'-
~, These lakcs are covered with the large leaves
Il, and in the proper season, the flowers of III


s'nymphea nelumbo," the largest and mos
ck splendid flower that have ever seen M,
er seen them of the size of the crown OF nal' I'll
nj external leaves Of the most brilliant WINE am


the internal of beautiful yellow 'hese lake


are so entirely covered with the large co''e'


leaves, nearly of the s;2c of a parasoi, and


smaller class of aquatic plant, of the same icri
ful of leaves. but with yellow flower, that a n'r
on might walk from shore to shore, without dpPlh
ng its feet in water; and these plants rise rom
OF depths of water, up to ten rect
be Beyond these lakes there arc immense swamp
It'll of cypress which swamps constitute vast poi
ri ton of the inundated lands OF Mississippi ana II
nc waters. No prospect on earth can oe N'"i
lb- gloomy The pactic Styx or Acheron had not
he greater union of dismal circumstances we
i'd m?y the cypress have been esteemed funert
- and lugubrous tree. When the tree has shc
)rs its leaves for it is dcciduous, cypress swami
ng with its countless intcrlaccd branches, oil hoa
lly nrev has an ASPECT of Gesolation and DEATH tho
ID, often as have been impressed with It, canne
&c, describe In summer its fine, short, ana Gee


green leaves invest these hoary branches WIN


drapcry of Grape. The water IN wmch the


rroy is n vast dead level, two or three feet deer
y" still leaving the innumerablc cypress Knees
10 ne thew are called, resembling circular oeehNc
=" throwing their points above the waters I'M
=! water is covered with thick coat OF green "'a
- ter, resembling green bull velvet. me mu'
ny outoes swarm above the water in countless mi
s., lions very frequent adjunct to TINS hoIilp.
~ scenery, is the moccason snake with his mug
M scav body lying in folds upon the SIDE OF cy
oo press knee; and if you approach too near, iaz
w and reckless as he is, he throws the upper jaw
nm his huge mouth, almost back to his neck, sNlh
oo Won ample warning of his ability ana wili 10 W ut
oo oo fsnd himself. travelled forty miles along tn
oo river swamp, and considerable part OF the wa
Nv in the edge of it; in which the horse SUNK az g


cry step half up to his knees was envelope
nm for the whole distance with cloud OF musslu
va 'oo toes Like the ancient Avcrn,s, do not r'
'oo membe to have seen single bird in the distanc
on 'oo except the blue jay. Nothing interrupted !,
W dcath.like silence, but the hum of musqu'toe

We have seen very ingenious and useful

me Muscles of the Human body, by means of
Plates peculiarly contlved-each muscle can be

Whole human frame, which will be great desd-
